In this work, a series of Co catalysts (namely Co@NC) was designed and developed from the thermal treatment of ZIF-67. Through extensive screening of various parameters, Co@NC700-H2/Ar exhibited the best catalytic performance in the acceptorless alcohol dehydrogenation to carboxylic acids. It was worth noting that Co@NC700-H2/Ar enabled the efficient synthesis of various aromatic and aliphatic carboxylic acids in moderate to high yields. Besides, it was recyclable for 9 consecutive cycles without activity decay. Moreover, the effects of pyrolysis conditions on the catalytic performance of the resulting materials were thoroughly examined, and the rationale for the superiority of Co@NC700-H2/Ar over the other prepared materials was also provided. Specifically, the pyrolysis atmosphere applying 95% of Ar gas and 5% of H2 gas (H2/Ar) resulted in the generation of ideal porosity and carbon nanotubes (CNTs), while utilizing 700 °C as the optimized pyrolysis temperature was ascribed to the comprehensive evaluation of materials crystallinity and defective structures. Furthermore, additional insights were gained by systematically exploring the oxidation states of Co in different catalysts. It was proposed that the Co–N species played a crucial role in this catalysis, while the contribution of other Co species, including Co0 and Co–O, could not be neglected. Finally, a plausible reaction mechanism was proposed based on the above observations and related literature reports. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords N-doped carbon ZIF-67 pyrolysis Acceptorless dehydrogenation Alcohols Carboxylic acids Data availability The raw data and the processed data required to reproduce these findings are available to download from Supplementary Information. 1 Introduction Carboxylic acids are of great significance and versatility to pharmaceutical and chemical industries, while the conversion of primary alcohols in the presence of an external oxidant is a well-established process for their synthesis [1]. Even if dioxygen gas (O2) could be employed as a mild oxidant [2–4], operational safety and functional group tolerance are the major drawbacks. Recently, an atom-economic and environmental-benign method for the preparation of carboxylic acids has been discovered via the acceptorless dehydrogenative coupling (ADC) of alcohols and water/hydroxides, with dihydrogen gas (H2) as the sole by-product. In most cases, the catalysts applied to this transformation are homogeneous [5–11]. Most of these catalysts exhibited good activity and high selectivity, but the relatively complicated synthesis became their main drawback. Accordingly, heterogeneous catalysts including Rh- [12], Pd- [13], Ag- [14,15], Co- [16,17], and Zn-based [18] ones have also been developed. Despite the development of the above catalysts, it is still in high demand to develop heterogeneous catalysts featuring facile synthetic methods, high catalytic performance and remarkable recyclability. From all the reported catalysts, it could be concluded that these catalysts are related to the active sites in their structure, which are composed of a Lewis acid site-basic site pair to efficiently catalyze the reactions. In recent years, various kinds of porous materials or even small organic molecules have been used as a sacrificial template to develop robust heterogeneous catalytic systems. For instance, Pd(Ph3P)4 and ferrocene have been explored to develop the corresponding heterogeneous catalysts [19,20]. Porous organic polymers (POPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have also been successfully explored to afford CoP- and CuFe2O4-based heterogeneous catalysts [21,22]. Among these porous materials, zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIFs), an important subclass of MOFs, have attracted growing attention because of their special zeolite-like structure and superior stability over the other structures [23–25]. More significantly, ZIFs possess the required Lewis acid site-basic site pair, with the metal center serving as a Lewis acid site and the imidazole fragment functioning as a basic site. Despite the above advantages, the stability of ZIFs is still not high enough compared with traditional porous materials, which restricted their applications under harsh conditions such as high temperature & pressure, and strong acidic/basic media [26]. Therefore, it is of great significance to inherit the merits of ZIFs while improving their stability. Nowadays, controlled thermal annealing has been demonstrated as an effective means to address the stability issues of ZIFs. Via this strategy, ZIFs can be converted into metal/metal oxides embedded in N-doped porous carbon (M@NC), which not only retain the excellent properties of ZIFs (large specific surface area and ordered pore structure, etc.) but also obtain better stability and more uniformly dispersed active sites than their parent materials [27–29]. It has been well documented that such ZIF-derived M@NC materials have been widely used in electrocatalysis [30–36], energy storage and conversion [37,38], adsorption [39–41], and microwave absorption [42–44]. Apart from these fields, their applications in catalytic organic transformations are at an early stage. Recently, M@NC-catalyzed oxidation [45,46], hydrogenation [47,48], CO2 fixation [49,50], and synthesis of nitrogen compounds from nitroarenes [51–53] have been successively reported. As a representative ZIF material, ZIF-67 has been widely used to construct the corresponding Co@NC materials [54–57]. Thus, our group also made a preliminary attempt by reporting a ZIF-67-derived Co@NC material as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for this transformation [58]. This catalyst performed well in terms of activity and recyclability, and it was fabricated and recycled in a facile and efficient manner. Therefore, it exhibited great potential for further practical applications, which prompted us to design and develop more efficient catalysts based on this catalyst. It is well-known that the morphology, composition, and porous properties of a catalytic material can be modulated to adjust its activity and stability. In terms of ZIF-derived materials obtained via controlled thermal annealing, pyrolysis atmospheres and pyrolysis temperature are two pivotal factors in regulating the properties of the resulting materials, thus tuning their catalytic performance. Pyrolysis at different atmospheres allows metal species to display various chemical states, which in turn affects the catalytic properties of the materials [59,60]. Concerning pyrolysis temperature, it was proven to have an important influence on the morphologies and crystallinity of the obtained materials, thus leading to different catalytic properties [61–63]. Thus, we herein intended to design and fabricate a series of Co catalysts embedded in N-doped carbon, while the main tasks of our study include the design of Co@NC by ZIF-67 carbonization; study of the effects of the pyrolysis temperature/atmospheres on textural, physicochemical and catalytic properties of Co@NC; investigation of the nature of active sites; as well as the catalytic potential of Co@NC. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Material preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of ZIF-67 The chemicals and solvents used in the reactions were purchased from commercial suppliers, and they were not further purified before use. The synthetic procedure of ZIF-67 followed our previous work [58]. 2-Methylimidazole (2-MIM, 1.32 g, 16.0 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (25 mL) at room temperature, sonicated in an ultrasonic apparatus for 5 min, and then the resulting solution was added dropwise to a solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (582 mg, 2.0 mmol) in methanol (25 mL) at 600 rpm. Subsequently, the mixed solution was stirred at the same speed for 24 h at room temperature. The solution was centrifuged at 8000 rpm for 5 min and washed with methanol three times. Finally, the collected precipitate was dried in a vacuum oven at 70°C for 24 h to obtain ZIF-67 as a purple powder. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Co@NC materials The synthesized ZIF-67 (about 200 mg) was uniformly distributed in a ceramic boat, which was placed in the center of a tube furnace (TL1200, Nanjing Boyuntong Instrument Technology Co. LTD) and pyrolyzed at a flow rate of 50 cm3/min under an argon gas stream containing 5% hydrogen gas (H2/Ar), a pure argon gas stream (Ar) or a pure nitrogen gas stream (N2). The temperature was ramped up from room temperature to 70°C at a heating rate of 1°C/min, then continuously heated to the target temperature (10°C/min) and held at this temperature for 2 h, and finally naturally cooled to room temperature to obtain Co@NC, namely Co@NCX-Y (X: 600, 700 or 800, Y: H2/Ar, N2, or Ar), as a black powder. Besides, the materials pyrolyzed for 1 h or 3 h were named Co@NC700-H2/Ar-1h or Co@NC700-H2/Ar-3h. The Co@NC700-H2/Ar catalyst was etched with concentrated hydrochloric acid (conc. HCl) at room temperature for 12 h or 9 M nitric acid (9 M HNO3) at 120°C for 4 h to afford Co@NC700-H2/Ar-HCl etched or Co@NC700-H2/Ar-HNO3 etched. 2.2 Characterization of chemicals and materials NMR spectra were recorded using a Bruker Avance 500 spectrometer (500 MHz for 1H NMR and 126 MHz for 13C NMR), with CDCl3, DMSO-d6 , or D2O as a deuterated solvent. The following abbreviations were used to designate multiplicity: s = singlet, d = doublet, t = triplet, q = quartet, p = pentet, m = multiplet, dd = doublet of doublets. The thermal stability of ZIF-67 was investigated on a Thermal Gravity Analysis (TGA, METTLER) under an N2 atmosphere. The materials morphologies were characterized using an electron scanning microscope (SEM, TESCAN MIRA3) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2F30). The elemental mapping was determined by energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) using an EDAX Genesis instrument. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (with a copper radiation source) to assess the crystal structure of the materials. The gas adsorption, surface area, and porosity properties were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Raman spectroscopy was recorded using a RENISHAW C-Raman instrument. Inductively coupled plasma emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Prodigy 7) analyses were done to measure the Co contents in the materials. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was applied using a Thermo Fischer ESCALAB 250XI instrument, with CasaXPS software for peak splitting fitting and data analyses. 2.3 The general procedure for a typical catalytic reaction Inside an argon-filled glovebox, Co@NCX-Y (10 mg), KOH (67.3 mg, 1.2 mmol), benzyl alcohol (104 μL, 1.0 mmol) and mesitylene (0.5 mL) were added in a 25 mL Schlenk tube. The tube was taken out of the glovebox and then heated at reflux under an argon atmosphere for 24 h. Afterwards, the tube was cooled to room temperature. The mixture was washed once with water (2 mL) and three times with methanol (5 mL), while a magnet was used to separate the catalyst. The methanol solution was concentrated, combined with the aqueous layer, and then acidified to pH = 2 using 3 N HCl solution (about 0.5 mL). Subsequently, the acidified mixture was transferred to a separatory funnel and extracted three times with ethyl acetate (10 mL). The collected organic layer was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated by a rotary evaporator. Furthermore, 1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene (0.5 mmol, 84.0 mg) and CDCl3 (1.0 mL) were added. Around 0.5 mL of the above solution was added to the NMR tube, which was directly subjected to 1H NMR analyses. The NMR yields of the acid product and the percentage of the unreacted alcohol were determined from the exact amount of 1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene. In addition, the isolation and purification of all acid products followed our previous work [8]. 2.4 Catalyst recycling The dehydrogenation of benzyl alcohol (1a) to benzoic acid (2a) under the standard catalytic conditions was selected for the recycling experiments. For each run, the same amounts of 1a, KOH, and mesitylene were utilized. In the first catalytic cycle, 10 mg of Co@NC700-H2/Ar was used. After the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture using an external magnet, washed once with water (2 mL), three times with methanol (5 mL), and dried under vacuum to ensure complete removal of organic compounds (2a, 1a, solvents or impurities). The process of recovering the catalyst was repeated for the next cycle. It was worth noting that 10 mg of the catalyst was only added in the first cycle, while no additional catalyst was added for the other catalytic cycles. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity of the as-synthesized Co@NC materials In this study, the reaction of benzyl alcohol (1a) and KOH was chosen as a template to evaluate the catalytic performance of Co@NC derived from the pyrolysis of ZIF-67 (Table 1 ). Firstly, the catalysts obtained at different pyrolysis atmospheres were studied (entries 1-3). To better compare the activity of these catalysts, reduced catalyst loadings and more substrate amounts based on our previous study [58] were initially utilized. It appeared that comparable results were achieved for the three atmospheres, with H2/Ar leading to slightly higher yields of 2a than N2 and Ar for both the 1st and 2nd runs (entries 1-3). Therefore, this atmosphere was selected for further investigations. Secondly, attempts to pyrolyze ZIF-67 at different temperatures were carried out (entries 3-5). The results indicated that pyrolysis at 700 °C surpassed the other two temperatures (600 and 800 °C) regarding the yield of 2a for both runs (entries 3-5). After confirming the ideal pyrolysis conditions, the optimized catalyst (Co@NC700-H2/Ar) was selected and subjected to further optimizations of other reaction conditions. Decreasing the weight of Co@NC700-H2/Ar led to a significantly reduced product yield (44% for entry 6 vs. 74% for entry 4), while increasing the catalyst amount from 10 mg to 15 mg gave rise to a comparable yield of 2a (76% for entry 7 vs. 74% for entry 4). Thus, the optimal catalyst dosage was determined to be 10 mg. Moreover, an extension of the reaction time from 24 h to 36 h resulted in an enhanced yield of 2a (entry 8), while a further elongation of the reaction period to 48 h led to a comparable outcome (entry 9). Therefore, 36 h was used for further studies. It has been well-documented that a solvent with a high donor number (DN) and a low acceptor number (AN) is beneficial for a base-mediated reaction because of its ability to activate a relatively acidic proton from the reactants [64,65]. Therefore, different solvents were screened to discuss role of solvent in this coupling process (entries 8, 10–13). It was worth noting that mesitylene still displayed the highest product yield. To provide a rationale for the superiority of mesitylene over the other solvents, the DN and AN values of all these solvents were obtained (as outlined in Table S1). A higher DN value of mesitylene (10.0) relative to that of m-xylene (5.0) and toluene (0.1) implied that mesitylene could effectively promote this reaction by providing the strongest basicity. Despite the high DN values of THF and 1,4-dioxane (20.0 and 14.3), their high AN values (8.0 and 10.3) might be the reason for their poor performance in this coupling reaction. Furthermore, different hydroxides were attempted, and KOH was identified as the best one for this reaction (entries 8, 14–15). Next, the solvent volume was screened (entries 8, 16–17), which indicated that the value was optimized as 0.25 mL (entry 16). For comparative studies, the situations applying Co powder, CoO, or no catalyst instead of Co@NC700-H2/Ar were tested (entries 18–20). For either Co powder or CoO, moderate yields of 2a were obtained for the 1st run, whereas reduced yields of this product were observed for the 2nd run (entries 18–19). Without any catalyst, almost no reaction occurred (entry 20). These control experiments revealed the advantages of Co@NC700-H2/Ar. Therefore, the optimized reaction conditions, recognized as 10 mg of Co@NC700-H2/Ar, 1.00 mmol of 1a, and 1.20 mmol of KOH in refluxing mesitylene (0.25 mL) for 36 h (entry 16), were used for further investigations. 3.2 Catalytic potential of Co@NC materials Under the optimal reaction conditions, a handful of alcohol substrates were selected to explore the substrate suitability of the current protocol (Scheme 1 ). At the outset, a number of aromatic alcohols were applied. For electronically distinct benzylic alcohols, electron-donating groups such as Me and iPr led to efficient formation of the corresponding acids (2b–2c) in 76–83% yields, whereas electron-withdrawing counterparts such as OCF3 and OH resulted in the generation of products 2d–2e in merely 33–36% yields. It was apparent that diphenyl- and naphthyl-containing alcohols 1f–1g were ideal coupling partners, which were smoothly converted into desired acid products 2f-2g. Interestingly, 4-methylbenzoic acid (2b), 3-methylbenzoic acid (2h), and 2-methylbenzoic acid (2i) were delivered in comparable yields, which represented that this Co@NC700-H2/Ar-catalyzed protocol was not sensitive to steric bulks attached to the phenyl ring. Besides, heteroatom-containing aromatic alcohols 1j–1l were also compatible, affording acid products 2j–2l in moderate to good yields. Apart from aromatic alcohols, aliphatic counterparts were also evaluated. Unlike little steric effects for aromatic alcohols, the catalytic system was quite sensitive to steric hindrance incorporated in aliphatic alcohols. Unhindered alcohols 1m–1o reacted smoothly with KOH to provide acids 2m–2o in high yields, whereas congested alcohols 1p–1q were less reactive since only low to moderate yields of the corresponding products (2p–2q) were furnished. It was noted that 1r, an aliphatic alcohol bearing a C=C bond, was selectively transformed into the hydrogenated product (2n) in a 41% yield, with no formation of the expected product (2r). Finally, the applicability of the current protocol in the transformation of amino alcohols into the corresponding amino acids was examined, and the desired products (2s–2t) were isolated in 41–70% yields. Comparison of the efficiency between Co@NC700-H2/Ar and all the reported heterogeneous catalysts in the literature was outlined in Table S2. The adsorption ability of a material surface is generally assessed by the point of zero charge (pzc) [66,67], which could be an important factor to influence the catalytic performance of the material. Thus, the zeta potential of Co@NC700-H2/Ar was evaluated over the pH range of 6-10, which indicated that the pzc of Co@NC700-H2/Ar was determined to be around 9 (Fig. S1). Although a strong base of KOH was involved in our reaction system, it was almost insoluble in mesitylene so the reaction solution should be slightly basic. At this point, the pH value of the reaction environment should be below the pzc of Co@NC700-H2/Ar, so the surface of the material was positively charged and was prone to adsorb anions from the reaction system. Indeed, the reaction mixture would generate K+ as the cation and several O-containing intermediates as the anions. Probably, the adsorption of these anions facilitated the catalytic reaction. As a pivotal factor for a heterogeneous catalyst, the recyclability of Co@NC700-H2/Ar was then evaluated by using the conversion of 1a into 2a under standard conditions. It is worth emphasizing that the recycling process was repeated 9 consecutive times and the yield of each run was maintained at about 80%, which indicated that the present catalyst exhibited good recyclability and high stability (Fig. 1 ). Moreover, the accumulated amounts of product 2a from per mg of a catalyst were calculated for both the current catalyst (Co@NC700-H2/Ar) and our previous catalyst (Co@NC600-H2/Ar) (as listed in Table S3). Notably, per mg of Co@NC700-H2/Ar was able to produce 90.9 mg of benzoic acid (2a) after 9 cycles, which was more than 200% as much as the value (40.2 mg) from our previous catalyst (Co@NC600-H2/Ar) after 15 cycles. 3.3 Effects of pyrolysis temperature and atmospheres To investigate the effects of catalyst synthesis (pyrolysis atmospheres and temperature) on the catalytic performance of all the synthesized Co@NC, in-depth investigations were conducted via a series of characterization tools. Initially, the TGA characterization of the precursor material (ZIF-67) was carried out to select the appropriate pyrolysis temperature (Fig. 2 ). From the TGA curve, it was observed that the deformation of ZIF-67 crystals started to occur when the temperature was up to 475°C, and the maximum weight loss rate was in the range of 500-650°C. Therefore, the temperature range of 600-800°C was chosen to prepare the corresponding catalysts. Next, the atmospheres for the pyrolysis process were investigated. In general, an inert gas atmosphere (Ar or N2) is primarily applied to prepare N-doped porous carbon from ZIF-67. In this way, the optimized N and C elements were maintained in the materials. In some cases, an argon gas stream containing a small ratio of hydrogen was also utilized to flexibly adjust the metal valences. Besides, the different cobalt species obtained after pyrolysis ZIF-67 and their involvement in the catalytic process were worth mentioning [58]. Therefore, the pyrolysis atmospheres (Ar, N2, and H2/Ar) were chosen for further experiments. After confirming the pyrolysis conditions, we continued to explore the relationship between rational design and the catalytic activity of the materials. Accordingly, a series of characterization techniques were adopted. From the SEM images, the surface of all the catalysts became rough after the carbonization processes (Fig. 3 a-c and Fig. S2). Under a pyrolysis atmosphere of N2, Ar, or H2/Ar, the rhombic dodecahedral structure is still maintained and the particle surfaces of the resultant Co@NC partially shrink (Fig. 3a and Fig. S2c-f). Moreover, trivial differences regarding the morphologies of the catalysts were observed despite the employment of different atmospheres (Fig. 3a vs. Fig. S2d vs. Fig. S2f). Interestingly, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) wrapping the rhombic dodecahedron were observed under the atmosphere of H2/Ar (Fig. 3a). The formation of CNTs could promote the deposition of Co species towards the end of CNTs so that more Co sites could be exposed, which could be a possible reason for the superiority of H2/Ar over the other two atmospheres in terms of catalytic efficiency. On the other hand, the surface became rougher and more CNTs were produced with decreasing crystal sizes (Fig. 3a-c), which may be due to the gradual collapse of the ZIF-67 crystals with the increase of the pyrolysis temperature. In addition, higher pyrolysis temperatures led to the wrapping of CNTs on the catalyst particles to more extents. This outcome indicated that the pyrolysis temperature did affect the morphologies of the obtained materials. During high-temperature pyrolysis, on one hand, Co ions were partially reduced to metallic Co by the carbon species of 2-MIM. On the other hand, the decomposition of 2-MIM produced high concentrations of N and C fragments around Co, thus promoting the formation of N-doped carbon (NC) embedded in Co [68]. According to literature reports, N-doping could form M–N active sites, provide basic properties, alleviate severe agglomeration of metal particles and facilitate the dispersion of metal species [69–71]. For the N 1s spectra, we found peaks for three main N species including pyridinic N (398.5 eV), pyrrolic N (399.9 eV), and graphitic N (401.1 eV) (Fig. S3-S6). Observation of Fig. S3b revealed that the N species did not vary greatly overall under different pyrolysis atmospheres. For different pyrolysis temperatures (Fig. S4b vs. Fig. S5b vs. Fig. S6b), the proportions of various N species did not differ greatly at 600°C and 700°C, while more pyrrolic N species were found for 800°C relative to the other two temperatures. Moreover, TEM characterization is used to identify Co species and graphitic carbon by measuring the lattice stripe spacing. As exemplified by the best-performing catalyst (Co@NC700-H2/Ar), it was observed that the graphitic carbon layer covered Co nanoparticles (Fig. 3d-e), which was in accordance with the literature reports [71–73]. The shell layers of the graphitic carbon promoted the uniform dispersion of Co nanoparticles, preventing metal agglomeration during high-temperature pyrolysis and metal leaching in the catalytic reaction. These results were also evidenced by the EDS analysis in which a uniform distribution of the C, O, N, and Co elements was detected (Fig. 3f-j). Indeed, the materials obtained via the pyrolysis of ZIF-67 in the literature also contain the element of O [58,73,74]. Probably, the precursor material (ZIF-67) is a porous material possessing a high surface area, so it could absorb small amounts of methanol (used in the preparation and purification of ZIF-67) as well as moisture and oxygen (derived from air). The above oxygen sources could be transformed into O-containing species (e.g. Co–O, C=O, N–O) during high-temperature treatment. Furthermore, the recycled catalyst was analyzed via SEM (Fig. S7) and TEM (Fig. S8). It was found that the morphology of the fresh Co@NC700-H2/Ar was not changed after the reaction, which indicated its morphological stability at high temperatures and under strongly alkaline conditions. Next, the effects of catalyst synthesis on the pore structure and surface area were investigated by N2 adsorption at 77 K (Fig. 4 , Fig. S9, and Table 2 ). The adsorption and desorption of N2 isotherm suggested strong adsorption at low pressure (P/P0 < 0.05) and a minor hysteresis loop at high pressure (P/P0 = 0.8-0.99). The N2 absorption matches with the N2 isotherm Type IV, in which the materials mainly contained microporous structures. Besides, the appearance of hysteresis loops represents the presence of certain mesopores (Fig. 4). In general, the hierarchical porosity (micro-/mesopores) of the materials facilitated the transport of substrate molecules and their interaction with the active catalytic center to promote the catalytic reaction [75]. It was found that H2/Ar led to a slightly larger pore size compared with N2 and Ar (Fig. S9 and Table 2), which might be another reason for its catalytic superiority over the other two atmospheres. As the pyrolysis temperature increased, the pore size marginally increased (Fig. S9 and Table 2), probably due to the damage of some pores in the catalysts at high temperature [76]. Besides, the enhancement of the pyrolysis temperature triggered the decrease of the specific surface area (Table 2), which was presumably because the Co particles were agglomerated to enlarge the particle size. Altogether, pyrolysis temperature/atmospheres affect the porous properties of the as-obtained materials, but the influence is not obvious. It was also worth mentioning that the optimal catalyst provided a high specific surface area to maximize the exposure of the active center and enhance the mass transfer and adsorption of reactants, which is required for catalysis [76]. To gain more valuable information, XRD, ICP, XPS, and Raman tests were then performed. The crystalline structure of the template material (ZIF-67) was destroyed after pyrolysis, as confirmed by the XRD pattern (Fig. 5 a-5b and Fig. S10) [77]. For all the carbonized materials, three peaks in the diffraction pattern were observed at 2θ of 44.2°, 51.5°, and 75.8°, corresponding to the crystal planes of Co (111), (200), and (220), respectively [78, 79]. It was noticed that the typical plane of graphitic carbon (002) was not spotted, which was probably due to the relatively low intensity of this plane relative to the characteristic Co peaks. Meanwhile, similar XRD patterns were observed for the catalysts obtained from different pyrolysis atmospheres (Fig. 5a). In contrast, the intensity of characteristic Co peaks gradually increased at higher pyrolysis temperature (Fig. 5b), which indicated the increased crystallinity of Co nanoparticles. Moreover, the effects of pyrolysis atmospheres/temperature on the average Co particle size were explored (Fig. S11). No obvious differences were observed for the average Co particle size under different pyrolysis atmospheres. In terms of different pyrolysis temperatures, the average Co particle size at 700°C was comparable with that at 600°C, whereas significantly larger Co particles were observed if the temperature was further increased to 800°C. These results indicated that pyrolysis at the high temperature of 800°C induced relatively large Co particles (probably due to severe Co agglomeration), while the other studied materials exhibited similar values regarding the average Co particle size. It is well known that high-temperature treatment on template materials would cause the agglomeration of metal atoms to generate larger metal particles [68,74]. As well, according to the ICP results (Table S4), the Co content was enhanced as the temperature was increased, while the values under different pyrolysis atmospheres did not differ much. Furthermore, the effect of structural defects on the catalytic performance was investigated by Raman analyses (Fig. 5c, d). The characteristic D band at 1340 cm−1 and the 2D band usually refer to disordered or defective carbon, while the representative G band at 1590 cm−1 is associated with graphitic sp2 carbon [80]. The band ratio between D and G (ID/IG ) was used to evaluate the material properties. As seen in Fig. 5c, the different pyrolysis atmospheres exhibited slight changes in the ID/IG ratios, indicating similar degrees of defects. In particular, the comparison between Co@NC600-H2/Ar and Co@NC600-Ar could be used to investigate the effect of hydrogenation on the carbon structure of the materials. By comparing the XPS C 1s (Fig. S3a) and Raman (Fig. 5c) results, the composition/proportion of C species and the degree of defects were not quite different for both materials, indicating that hydrogenation did not have an obvious impact on the carbon structure of the materials. In contrast, significant differences in the ID/IG ratios were found for different pyrolysis temperatures, with reduced ID/IG ratios at higher pyrolysis temperature (Fig. 5d). The increased pyrolysis temperature promotes the graphitization of carbon, which could be caused by decreasing defect structure of the catalysts. At different pyrolysis temperatures, the ID/IG ratio of Co@NC700-H2/Ar was similar to that of Co@NC600-H2/Ar, which means that they possess comparable defect sites. However, Co@NC700-H2/Ar exhibited higher crystallinity than Co@NC600-H2/Ar, as evidenced by the XRD patterns of the two materials (Fig. 5b). Moreover, the ID/IG ratio of Co@NC700-H2/Ar was higher than that of Co@NC800-H2/Ar, which represented that Co@NC700-H2/Ar exhibited more defect sites than Co@NC800-H2/Ar. Indeed, higher defect sites could imply more open sites (active sites) with the potential to promote catalytic activity. On the other hand, the over-optimized pyrolysis temperature (800°C) could cause severe agglomeration of Co particles. Therefore, the above discussions could explain why the pyrolyzed template at 700°C exhibited the best catalytic performance [74]. It was also worth noting that the XRD pattern of Co@NC700-H2/Ar did not change much before and after the reaction, which further indicated the structural stability of the catalyst under the reaction conditions (Fig. S12). 3.4 Study on the oxidation states of Co in different catalysts To gain more insights into the oxidation states of Co in different catalysts, systematic investigations were carried out for both fresh and recycled Co@NC700-H2/Ar, aided by XPS analyses (Fig. 6 and Fig. S13). For the Co 2p spectra, the binding energies of the Co 2p3/2 peaks at 781.6 eV, 780.1 eV, and 778.2 eV correspond to Co–N, Co–O, and Co0 species, respectively, and the corresponding Co 2p1/2 peaks are located at 797.2 eV, 795.3 eV, and 793.1 eV, respectively, along with two satellite peaks at the energy levels [81–84]. A comparison between the fresh and recycled catalysts indicated that the composition of the Co species was almost identical, whereas the ratio of these Co species was quite different (Fig. 6a vs. Fig. 6b, Table S5). In particular, an increase in the percentage of Co–N species and a decrease in that of Co0 species were clearly observed after the reaction. The same trend could also be seen from the XPS spectra (Fig. 7 a vs. Fig. S4c) and the distribution of various Co species (Table S6) for Co@NC600-H2/Ar. As indicated in entries 1-5 of Table 1, the product yield of the second cycle was found to be always higher than that of the first one. Probably, the improved yields for the catalysts after reaction were attributed to the increased percentage of Co–N species, which could further support our previous proposition that the Co–N species played an important role in this catalysis [58]. Moreover, according to the ICP results, the Co contents under all circumstances were reduced after the reaction (Table S4). In combination with the above XPS results, it was supposed that leaching of Co0 species mainly occurred, whereas most Co–N species were stably present in the material and crucial for this transformation. Apart from Co–N species, other Co species including Co–O and Co0 were also present in our materials. Therefore, further exploration was performed. According to the comparative experimental results from cobalt powder (a Co0 species) and CoO (a Co–O species), it could be seen that they manifested comparable catalytic performance, producing product 2a in moderate yields of 47-55% for the first cycle and even reduced yields of 38-48% for the second cycle (entries 18-19, Table 1). In addition, the Co 2p spectra of different atmospheres (Fig. 7) and temperature (Fig. 6a vs Fig. S6c) revealed that the catalytic potency did not differ much with different ratios of Co–O/Co0. Specifically, the Co 2p spectra of XPS (Fig. 7a and Fig. 7b) implied that the percentage of Co–O decreased and that of Co0 species increased in the presence of a small amount of hydrogen, suggesting that hydrogenation promoted the generation of low-valence Co0 species. In addition, by comparing the catalytic performance of the two materials (entry 1 vs. entry 3, Table 1), it could be found that hydrogenation had little effect on this catalytic process, which indicated that both Co0 and Co–O were also important for this catalytic transformation. To gain more useful information about the oxidation states of Co and their significance in this catalysis, additional exploration was carried out. The materials synthesized at different carbonization times (1 h, 2 h, and 3 h) were prepared and characterized, and their catalytic performance was also evaluated. Both XRD and XPS results showed that the proportion of zero-valent cobalt gradually increased with elongated carbonization periods (Fig. 8 a, Fig. S14, and Table S7). In terms of the catalytic activity, the above three materials led to comparable yields of product 2a, with the carbonization time of 2 h exhibiting slightly higher yields than the periods of 1 h and 3 h (as listed in entries 1-3 of Table S8). It could be concluded that an appropriate proportion of zero-valent cobalt was beneficial for this catalytic process. It was also noted that the carbonization time influenced the catalytic activity of the materials, but the effect was not significant. Moreover, acid etching experiments were performed. Accordingly, the best-performing catalyst (Co@NC700-H2/Ar) was etched with concentrated HCl and HNO3, denoted as Co@NC700-H2/Ar-HCl etched and Co@NC700-H2/Ar-HNO3 etched, respectively. Besides, the characterization and catalytic performance of the above materials were evaluated. Compared with Co@NC700-H2/Ar, Co@NC700-H2/Ar-HCl etched displayed comparable activity for the coupling of 1a with KOH to afford 2a, whereas Co@NC700-H2/Ar-HNO3 etched exhibited a significantly reduced yield (entries 2, 4 and 5, Table S8). From TEM and XPS analyses, no obvious changes were observed for the morphologies and chemical states after HCl etching (Fig. 8b and Fig. S15). Specifically, etching with conc. HCl could not effectively remove the zerovalent Co in the material, while it merely eliminated some large/unstable Co nanoparticles so that the average particle size of the zerovalent Co was reduced (Fig. 8b and Fig. S15a-b). Therefore, Co@NC700-H2/Ar-HCl etched exhibited almost identical catalytic performance relative to Co@NC700-H2/Ar. However, etching with concentrated HNO3 destroyed the material's structure to a large extent, which is consistent with the literature report [85]. It was observed that a large number of Co nanoparticles, along with other Co species such as Co–N and Co–O, were removed (Fig. 8b and Fig. S15c-d), which was probably the reason for the significant reduction in the catalytic performance of the material after etching with concentrated HNO3. 3.5 Explanation of the proposed reaction mechanism Based on all the above observations and related literature reports [17,58], we provided a plausible mechanism for the Co@NC700-H2/Ar catalyzed dehydrogenative coupling (Scheme 2 ). In the first step, Co@NC700-H2/Ar enables the dehydrogenation of alcohol 1 to afford the corresponding aldehyde (3), with the evolvement of one H2 molecule. Subsequently, treatment of 3 with KOH delivers intermediate I, which could be converted into the desired product via two possible pathways. For the first pathway (Pathway 1), intermediate I eliminates another H2 molecule to directly furnish the carboxylate. For the second pathway (Pathway 2), I and 3 undergo a Cannizzaro reaction to provide one molecule of 1 and one molecule of the carboxylate [7,86,87], while the produced alcohol (1) is further transformed into the carboxylate in either of the two pathways. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have designed and fabricated a handful of Co@NC materials through controlled pyrolysis of ZIF-67. Through extensive investigations, the best-performing material (Co@NC700-H2/Ar) exhibited high catalytic activity and good recyclability for the alcohol dehydrogenation to carboxylic acids. Under the optimal reaction conditions, Co@NC700-H2/Ar was able to convert a wide range of alcohols into the corresponding carboxylic acids. Moreover, a series of characterization techniques were adopted to evaluate the effects of pyrolysis atmospheres/temperature on the structure, morphologies, and porous properties of the resulting materials, which were highly correlated with their catalytic performance. It was concluded that the pyrolysis atmosphere of H2/Ar led to optimal porous properties and the formation of CNTs, while the selection of 700°C as the optimal pyrolysis temperature was based on the comprehensive consideration of material crystallinity and structural defects. Finally, additional studies were carried out to probe the oxidation states of Co in different catalysts. It was proposed that Co–N was of great significance for this transformation, while Co0 and Co–O also played important roles in promoting this catalytic process. coredata.dc:description: In this work, a series of Co catalysts (namely Co@NC) was designed and developed from the thermal treatment of ZIF-67. Through extensive screening of various parameters, Co@NC700-H2/Ar exhibited the best catalytic performance in the acceptorless alcohol dehydrogenation to carboxylic acids. It was worth noting that Co@NC700-H2/Ar enabled the efficient synthesis of various aromatic and aliphatic carboxylic acids in moderate to high yields. Besides, it was recyclable for 9 consecutive cycles without activity decay. Moreover, the effects of pyrolysis conditions on the catalytic performance of the resulting materials were thoroughly examined, and the rationale for the superiority of Co@NC700-H2/Ar over the other prepared materials was also provided. Specifically, the pyrolysis atmosphere applying 95% of Ar gas and 5% of H2 gas (H2/Ar) resulted in the generation of ideal porosity and carbon nanotubes (CNTs), while utilizing 700 °C as the optimized pyrolysis temperature was ascribed to the comprehensive evaluation of materials crystallinity and defective structures. Furthermore, additional insights were gained by systematically exploring the oxidation states of Co in different catalysts. It was proposed that the Co–N species played a crucial role in this catalysis, while the contribution of other Co species, including Co0 and Co–O, could not be neglected. Finally, a plausible reaction mechanism was proposed based on the above observations and related literature reports.
coredata.dc:title: Rational design of cobalt catalysts embedded in N-Doped carbon for the alcohol dehydrogenation to carboxylic acids
